articles.headline: Support package granted for pubs and venues
articles.author: Gabriel Dela Cruz

exemption_status.exemption_notes: Not a match report, preview, live bulletin, or video/audio-only content

story_classification.reasoning: Policy announcement story focused on government support package for pubs and venues. Sources are policymakers and industry representatives discussing business rates policy.

beat_context.beat_notes: Business rates policy affecting hospitality sector

quoted_sources.name: Dan Tomlinson
quoted_sources.title: Treasury Minister
quoted_sources.role_reasoning: Government minister announcing and defending the support package policy. Holds institutional power to shape policy outcomes.
quoted_sources.quote_context: Stated the three-year package would provide approximately £1,650 for the average pub in 2026-2027. Emphasized pubs as 'the cornerstone of so many communities.'

quoted_sources.name: Mel Stride
quoted_sources.title: Shadow Chancellor
quoted_sources.role_reasoning: Senior opposition politician providing political critique of government policy. Holds institutional position of influence.
quoted_sources.quote_context: Dismissed the measure as insufficient, questioning 'Is this it?' and warning measures would 'only delay the pain for a while.'

quoted_sources.name: Daisy Cooper
quoted_sources.title: Liberal Democrat Treasury Spokesperson
quoted_sources.role_reasoning: Political spokesperson representing party position on economic policy. Holds institutional political power.
quoted_sources.quote_context: Noted pubs still face higher bills and other high street businesses receive 'nothing at all.' Recommended broader discounts and VAT cut.

quoted_sources.name: Emma McClarkin
quoted_sources.title: Chief Executive of the British Beer and Pub Association
quoted_sources.role_reasoning: Industry association leader representing sector interests. Holds institutional power to influence policy through organized advocacy.
quoted_sources.quote_context: Pledged organizational support while pursuing long-term business rate reforms.

individuals: Emma McClarkin (British Beer and Pub Association CEO)

implementation_power.description: Government departments, regulatory bodies implementing the business rates changes
individuals: Office for Budget Responsibility (mentioned, not quoted)

direct_impact.description: Individual pub owners, music venue operators, hospitality business owners affected by rates

indirect_impact.description: Pub employees, musicians, local communities served by pubs and venues

articles.headline: BCP Council Vote on Tax Base Proposal
articles.author: Julia Apte

exemption_status.exemption_notes: Not a match report, preview, live bulletin, or video/audio-only content

story_classification.reasoning: Local government policy story about council tax decision affecting beach hut owners. Sources are council members and community association representative discussing policy decision.

beat_context.beat_notes: Council tax policy and local government finance

quoted_sources.name: Millie Earl
quoted_sources.title: Council Leader
quoted_sources.role_reasoning: Council leader with institutional power to set policy and make budget decisions. Holds top elected position in local government.
quoted_sources.quote_context: Explained financial pressures facing the council, noting they are 'likely to lose £20 million over the next three years from the various grant we get.'

quoted_sources.name: Darren Pidwell
quoted_sources.title: Chair of the Mudeford and Sandbanks Beach hut Association
quoted_sources.role_reasoning: Represents beach hut owners directly affected by the council tax decision. Though holds leadership position in association, primarily speaks for those experiencing policy impact.
quoted_sources.quote_context: Expressed frustration about council 'targeting Mudeford and Sandbanks hut owners to raise additional revenues and with no prior consultation.'

quoted_sources.name: Mike Cox
quoted_sources.title: Christchurch Councillor
quoted_sources.role_reasoning: Elected councillor with voting power on policy decisions. Holds institutional government position.
quoted_sources.quote_context: Acknowledged burden on some residents, expressing 'sympathy for those who inherited their beach hut and are not individually wealthy themselves.'

quoted_sources.name: David Brown
quoted_sources.title: Bearwood and Merley Councillor
quoted_sources.role_reasoning: Elected councillor defending policy decision. Holds institutional government position with policy-making power.
quoted_sources.quote_context: Defended decision's impact on vulnerable groups, noting they 'haven't pulled the Local Council Support Scheme.'

quoted_sources.name: Richard Harrett
quoted_sources.title: Wallisdown and Winton West Councillor
quoted_sources.role_reasoning: Elected councillor with policy-making power. Holds institutional government position.
quoted_sources.quote_context: Noted beach hut association's frustrations about 'lack of investment in the view along the seafront.'

quoted_sources.name: Andy Martin
quoted_sources.title: Highcliffe and Walkford Councillor
quoted_sources.role_reasoning: Elected councillor highlighting policy rationale. Holds institutional government position.
quoted_sources.quote_context: Highlighted revenue impact: 'The revenue that we will accrue from this is £211,000 which is a huge amount of money.'

structural_power.description: Council leaders, elected councillors with policy-making authority
individuals: Richard Harrett (Wallisdown and Winton West Councillor)

implementation_power.description: Council staff, tax collection departments implementing the policy

direct_impact.description: Beach hut owners at Mudeford and Sandbanks facing tax increases
individuals: Darren Pidwell (Beach hut Association Chair, representing owners)
Beach hut owners who inherited huts

indirect_impact.description: Residents benefiting from services funded by increased revenue, low-income residents on Local Council Support Scheme
